items.title: NFR team roper, NFSR competitor Corky Warren passes away at 87
items.description: Corky Warren, a two-time qualifier for the National Finals Rodeo and one-time qualifier for the National Finals Steer Roping, passed away Jan. 22, in Cleburne, Texas. He was 87. Corky’s passion for rodeo, and specifically...
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Corky Warren, a two-time qualifier for the National Finals Rodeo (NFR) and one-time qualifier for the National Finals Steer Roping (NFSR), passed away on January 22, 2026 in Cleburne, Texas at the age of 87.

- Corky was a successful rodeo competitor, winning individual event championships at major rodeos like Calgary, Phoenix, Cheyenne, Denver, and San Antonio.

- He competed as a team roping heeler at the 1973 and 1974 NFRs, placing in multiple rounds and finishing 5th and 7th in the average, respectively.

- At the 1973 NFSR, Corky finished 15th in the world standings and placed 4th in two rounds.

- Corky also won two all-around championships in the Senior Pro Rodeo Association and two world titles in steer roping while competing in the Senior Steer Roping Association.

- His success earned him induction into the Cheyenne Frontier Days Hall of Fame and the Texas Pro Rodeo Cowboy Hall of Fame.

- After his rodeo career, Corky went on to train championship quarter horses and design/build top equestrian centers and arenas in the West.

- Corky was described as humble and not one to boast about his accomplishments, leaving his brother Bob in "awe of his legacy."

items.title: Garrett Shadbolt, Jacek Frost to miss time due to injuries
items.description: Two months ago, bareback riders Jacek Frost and Garrett Shadbolt were competing at the Wrangler National Finals Rodeo while dealing with injuries that were disrupting their performances. Both are now rehabilitating different injuries. Shadbolt had...
items.summary:
Shadbolt, a 29-year-old 4-time National Finals Rodeo (NFR) qualifier from Merriman, Nebraska, had surgery on February 3rd to remove a bone spur in his left hip that had been bothering him for about a year. He is looking to return to action towards the end of June, aiming to compete at the Reno Rodeo.

Frost, a 21-year-old from Browns Valley, California, had an operation on January 28th to reattach the labrum in his left shoulder that was damaged during the recent NFR. He placed in just one round at the NFR and finished 13th in the PRCA | Bill Fick Ford World Standings. 

Both cowboys are hoping to be back competing by late June. Their injuries had been significantly impacting their performances, with Shadbolt saying he had been riding with discomfort for over a year and Frost losing power and ability to stay square due to the shoulder issue.

The article includes quotes from both Shadbolt and Frost describing their injuries and surgery details. It also mentions the doctors who performed the procedures - Dr. J.W. Thomas Byrd in Nashville for Shadbolt, and Dr. Travis Kieckbusch in Reno for Frost.

items.title: Wrangler South Dakota High School Rodeo Showcase Results

items.title: Sage Newman Capitalizes in Rodeo Rapid City Xtreme Broncs
items.description: PRCA Xtreme Broncs opened with excitement on January 31, 2026, featuring four sectionsof competition before culminating in a short-go to determine the top riders and payouts.South Dakota native Eastan West set the tone early with...
items.summary:
Sage Newman captured the win at the PRCA Xtreme Broncs event in Rapid City, South Dakota on January 31, 2026. 

The event featured four sections of competition before a short-go round to determine the top riders and payouts. South Dakota native Eastan West set the tone early with an 82.5-point ride on Daidra's Pet.

In the final short-go round, Sage Newman drew Summit Pro Rodeo's Cowboy Fool and delivered an electrifying 89.5-point performance to claim the event win and the top payout of $4,000.64.

Other top finishers include:
- Brody Wells, Powell, WY - 88.5 points, $2,500.40 
- Shorty Garrett, Eagle Butte, SD - 88.5 points, $2,500.40
- Eastan West, New Underwood, SD - 87.5 points, $1,000.16

The event payouts were as follows:
1st - Sage Newman - $4,000.64
2nd - Brody Wells, Shorty Garrett - $2,500.40 each
4th - Eastan West - $1,000.16

The other section winners and their prize money were:
1st Section: Eastan West - $2,250.36, Tanner Butner - $1,500.24
2nd Section: Gus Gaillard - $2,250.36, Shorty Garrett - $1,500.24 
3rd Section: Brody Wells - $1,875.30, Sage Newman - $1,875.30
4th Section: Cash Wilson - $1,875.30, Lane Schuelke - $1,875.30

items.title: NCBA Releases 2026 Policy Priorities at CattleCon
items.description: NASHVILLE, TENNESSEE (February 2, 2026) ‚Äì The National Cattlemen’s Beef Association (NCBA) today announced its 2026 policy priorities following approval by the organization’s Executive Committee at CattleCon 2026. NCBA’s focus centers on policies that directly...
items.summary:
The National Cattlemen's Beef Association (NCBA) has announced its 2026 policy priorities following approval by the organization's Executive Committee at CattleCon 2026. The focus is on policies that directly impact producer profitability, including reducing regulatory costs, defending free markets, expanding trade opportunities, and maintaining strong beef demand.

Key points:
- NCBA's 2025 efforts resulted in key tax and regulatory improvements, including expanded estate tax exemptions, a new Waters of the U.S. rules, and the rescission of the Bureau of Land Management Public Lands Rule.
- NCBA's 2026 policy agenda focuses on strengthening producer profitability and addressing emerging challenges across the cattle business.
- NCBA's 2026 policy priorities include:
  - Continuing to press the administration to roll back harmful regulations to keep working lands working.
  - Enhancing and strengthening U.S. mitigation measures against the incursion of New World Screwworm.
  - Protecting the U.S. cattle herd from foreign animal diseases and pests through heightened awareness and preparedness actions.
  - Expanding market access for U.S. beef exports and holding trade partners accountable to ensure equivalent animal health and food safety standards for imported beef.
  - Promoting science-based nutrition policies and sound, fact-based information for consumers.
  - Pushing for further hours-of-service flexibility, increased truck weights, and continuing to delay ELD requirements for livestock haulers.
  - Safeguarding the U.S cattle and beef supply chain by working with the administration to ensure there is a strong workforce to limit processing disruptions for producers.

items.title: American Egg Board Aims to Spur Rapid Export Growth
items.description: CHICAGO ‚Äî American Egg Board (AEB) leadership and U.S. egg producers are accompanying officials from the USDA Foreign Agricultural Service and state departments of agriculture, agribusiness executives and representatives from other U.S. commodities on a trade mission to Jakarta, Indonesia, Feb. 2-5, 2026. The trade mission is the first in a series of strategic international […] The post American Egg Board Aims to Spur Rapid Export Growth appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
S. egg and egg product exports. Currently, the U.S. exports only 3-4% of total egg production annually, while other animal-sourced agricultural commodities export 15-30% of domestic production.

The trade mission aims to catalyze expansion of U.S. egg exports to diversify sales and address low domestic wholesale egg prices. Indonesia is an attractive market, being the 4th most populous nation and a major importer of processed egg ingredients. A new 2025 U.S.-Indonesia trade deal has removed tariffs on over 99% of U.S. agricultural products.

American Egg Board CEO Emily Metz said exports are a "critical and largely untapped" opportunity for U.S. egg producers to create new demand, improve returns, and increase stability. Trade mission delegate Sean Delano of Mid-States Specialty Eggs noted the international appetite for U.S. egg quality and attributes like safety, production standards, organic, and halal.

The USDA trade mission agenda includes networking, meetings with importers and officials, facility tours, and cultural events. The AEB is also planning additional engagement in key markets like the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Vietnam, South Korea, and Japan throughout 2026.

items.title: IALF Awards 118 Agriculture in the Classroom Grants
items.description: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa — The Iowa Agriculture Literacy Foundation (IALF) has awarded 118 Agriculture in the Classroom (AITC) Teacher Supplement Grants to Iowa educators, advancing its mission to build agricultural literacy through hands-on, standards-aligned experiences for students across the state. The IALF AITC Teacher Supplement Grant program provides up to $200 per project to support new or expanded […] The post IALF Awards 118 Agriculture in the Classroom Grants appeared first o
items.summary:
The grants, worth up to $200 each, will fund hands-on, standards-aligned agricultural learning experiences for students across the state. 

49 of the 118 grantees are receiving IALF funding for agricultural education for the first time. Projects will cover topics like farm robotics, culinary education, crop/animal lifecycles, pollinators, renewable energy, and more. 

The grants are supported by the Iowa Farm Bureau Federation, which believes agricultural literacy is vital for helping students understand agriculture's impact on their communities. Educators plan to use the funds for classroom lessons, instructional materials, guest speakers, field trips, and real-world applications.

For example, at Prairie Point Middle School in Cedar Rapids, students will study greenhouse systems through literacy and science. At Albia Community Schools, students will explore Iowa agriculture through cooking labs, farmer visits, and recipe cards highlighting local foods.

IALF's executive director praised the grants for providing a real-world context for learning across subjects like science, math, language arts, and career exploration. The full list of 118 grant recipients, organized by county and city, is included.

items.title: United Producers Inc. 2026 Scholarship Deadline Approaching
items.description: COLUMBUS, Ohio ‚Äî United Producers Inc. (UPI) reminds students that the deadline to apply for its 2026 Scholarship Program is quickly approaching. Applications must be submitted by March 1, 2026. UPI will award 10 scholarships valued at $1,500 each to graduating high school seniors from the Class of 2026 pursuing education at a college or […] The post United Producers Inc. 2026 Scholarship Deadline Approaching appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- United Producers Inc. (UPI) is offering 10 scholarships worth $1,500 each to graduating high school seniors from the Class of 2026 pursuing higher education.

- The deadline to apply for the 2026 UPI Scholarship Program is March 1, 2026.

- Eligible applicants include UPI members or children/grandchildren of UPI members. Non-members can also apply with a nomination from a current UPI member.

- Applicants must submit an application and an essay outlining their college and career goals.

- UPI serves 30,000 members in 6 states (Ohio, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, and Tennessee) and handles approximately 2.7 million head of livestock per year.

- UPI offers various services including risk management, marketing agreements, brokerage services, and agricultural lending products.

- The scholarship program is part of UPI's efforts to support the future of agriculture.

items.title: Cattle futures see more gains ahead of week’s direct trade
items.description: Chicago Mercantile Exchange live and feeder cattle futures closed higher, supported by the tight market ready numbers, getting ready for the week‚Äôs direct cash business. Contracts did close below the session highs due to modest midday losses in beef and overbought signals. April live was up $.17 at $241.80 and June was $.60 higher at […] The post Cattle futures see more gains ahead of week’s direct trade appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
The key points from the article are:

Cattle futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange closed higher, with April live cattle up $0.17 to $241.80 and June up $0.60 to an unspecified price. This was driven by tight supplies of market-ready cattle ahead of the week's direct cash trade. Futures did close below session highs due to some midday declines in the beef market and signals the market may be overbought. Traders are anticipating the upcoming week's direct cash cattle trade.

items.title: Second RFP issued addressing H5N1 risk to swine
items.description: SHIC, FFAR and Pork Checkoff invite proposals for research projects on H5N1 influenza prevention, preparedness, mitigation and response capabilities in U.S. swine herd.
items.summary:
SHIC (Swine Health Information Center), FFAR (Foundation for Food & Agriculture Research), and Pork Checkoff have issued a second Request for Proposals (RFP) for research projects addressing the H5N1 avian influenza threat to the U.S. swine herd. The RFP aims to support projects that enhance prevention, preparedness, mitigation, and response capabilities for the swine industry. 

Key details:
- Proposals are due by January 18, 2023.
- Up to $750,000 in total funding is available.
- Projects should focus on one or more of these areas: biosecurity, surveillance, diagnostics, disease modeling, or response planning.
- Eligible applicants include universities, research institutions, and private companies.

The recent outbreak of highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza has raised concerns about the potential for the virus to spread to pigs. Swine can act as "mixing vessels" where avian and human influenza strains can combine, leading to the emergence of new pandemic threats. Protecting the U.S. swine herd is crucial to safeguarding both animal and public health.

This RFP follows an earlier $500,000 funding announcement in October 2022 for similar research projects. The goal is to build on past work and further strengthen the swine industry's preparedness and response capabilities against the H5N1 risk.

items.title: February is National Pesticide Safety Education Month
items.description: COLUMBIA, Mo. ‚Äì February is National Pesticide Safety Education Month, a time to promote vigilance and best safety practices on the farm, said Sam Polly, coordinator of University of Missouri Extension‚Äôs Pesticide Safety Education Program, which has provided commercial pesticide recertification training to about 1,000 Missourians in the past year. Based on Environmental Protection Agency and National […] The post February is National Pesticide Safety Education Month appeared first on Morni
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- February is National Pesticide Safety Education Month, a time to promote best safety practices for pesticide use in agriculture, landscaping, and structural pest control.

- University of Missouri (MU) Extension's Pesticide Safety Education Program has provided training to about 1,000 Missouri pesticide applicators in the past year. 

- Based on EPA and NIOSH estimates, MU Extension's program saves Missouri $10-$17 million per year across different industries.

- The Weed Science Society of America, American Phytopathological Society, and Entomological Society of America urge people to review safety practices during this month.

- Key safety topics include reading pesticide labels, spill response, worker protection standards, and protecting pollinators/wildlife.

- MU Extension has online quizzes to test pesticide safety knowledge.

- The goal is to promote safe pesticide use for healthy crops, environmental protection, and worker safety.

items.title: Statesville Kiwanis Club Donates $20,000 to Support 4-H Youth Programming
items.description: STATESVILLE, N.C. — The Statesville Kiwanis Club has made a generous $20,000 donation to Iredell County 4-H and Iredell County Cooperative Extension to help purchase a 15-passenger van, expanding youth programming opportunities across the county. The van will be used to safely transport 4-H youth to educational programs, community service projects, camps, and leadership events […] The post Statesville Kiwanis Club Donates $20,000 to Support 4-H Youth Programming appeared first on Mor
items.summary:
The Statesville Kiwanis Club has donated $20,000 to Iredell County 4-H and Iredell County Cooperative Extension to purchase a 15-passenger van. This van will be used to transport 4-H youth to educational programs, community service projects, camps, and leadership events throughout Iredell County and beyond. 

The donation was made on February 4, 2026. It is expected to directly address the challenge of reliable transportation for local 4-H programs, allowing more youth to participate in hands-on learning, leadership opportunities, and community service projects. 

The donation was facilitated by the Iredell County Agricultural Fair Chair Jim Head and the Fair Board members, who have a long-standing commitment to supporting youth development and agriculture in the community. 

Iredell County Extension Director Laura Elmore emphasized that the support from the Statesville Kiwanis Club reflects a shared commitment to investing in young people, and that the van will serve thousands of youth over its lifetime, strengthening the ability to deliver high-quality Extension and 4-H programming across the county.

The Statesville Kiwanis Club is known for its dedication to improving the lives of children through service and community partnerships, and this contribution aligns with Kiwanis' mission of supporting youth development and education.

items.title: Transportation costs adding pressure to farmers, expert says
items.description: An ag transportation expert says maintaining a reliable and efficient supply chain is critical as pressures mount across agriculture. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot of stress among farmers,‚Äù said Mike Steenhoek with the Soy Transportation Coalition. Steenhoek says transportation costs have a direct impact a farm‚Äôs financial performance. ‚ÄúIf you have a costly, cumbersome, inefficient and unreliable […] The post Transportation costs adding pressure to farmers, expert says appeared first on Brownfield Ag New
items.summary: Transportation costs are adding significant pressure on farmers, according to Mike Steenhoek from the Soy Transportation Coalition. The expert says maintaining a reliable and efficient supply chain is critical as various pressures mount across the agricultural sector. Steenhoek noted that transportation costs directly impact a farm's financial performance, with costly, cumbersome, inefficient, and unreliable transportation systems negatively affecting farmers' bottom lines. The article did not provide specific numbers or statistics, but the overall message is that rising transportation costs are a major challenge for farmers that needs to be addressed to ensure the viability of agricultural operations.

items.title: IPWA‚ÄìIEF partnership aims to strengthen poultry welfare education worldwide
items.description: The International Poultry Welfare Alliance and International Egg Foundation have signed a memorandum of understanding to strengthen poultry welfare training around the world. Elena Myhre with the International Poultry Welfare Alliance tells Brownfield “this is something we’ve made in collaboration with a lot of U.S. poultry producers and now, they’re able to be a leader […] The post IPWA‚ÄìIEF partnership aims to strengthen poultry welfare education worldwide appeared first
items.summary:
The International Poultry Welfare Alliance (IPWA) and the International Egg Foundation (IEF) have signed a memorandum of understanding to strengthen poultry welfare training globally. 

The partnership aims to improve poultry welfare education worldwide. Elena Myhre from the IPWA stated that this collaboration involves many U.S. poultry producers, allowing them to become leaders in this initiative.

The key goals of the IPWA-IEF partnership are to:
- Develop standardized poultry welfare training programs 
- Provide access to these programs for poultry producers around the world
- Enhance knowledge and implementation of best practices for poultry welfare

This partnership is expected to have a positive impact on poultry farmers by equipping them with the necessary skills and resources to improve animal welfare on their farms. The collaboration between the IPWA and IEF will leverage their combined expertise and reach to achieve these objectives globally.

items.title: Iowa soybean leaders eye 45Z guidance, EPA action to boost biofuel demand
items.description: Biofuels policy was a focus of the Iowa Soybean Association‚Äôs Farm Forward Conference. Iowa Soybean Association president Tom Adam says the U.S. Treasury‚Äôs proposed guidance on the 45Z tax credit is encouraging. ‚ÄúIt will limit tax credits to production using North American feedstocks. And also takes away the carbon intensity score due to indirect land […] The post Iowa soybean leaders eye 45Z guidance, EPA action to boost biofuel demand appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The Iowa Soybean Association is focused on biofuels policy to boost demand for soybeans. The U.S. Treasury's proposed guidance on the 45Z tax credit is seen as encouraging by the association's president, Tom Adam. The guidance will limit tax credits to production using North American feedstocks and remove the carbon intensity score due to indirect land use changes. The Iowa Soybean Association is also looking to the EPA to take action to increase biofuel demand, which could benefit soybean farmers in the state.

items.title: American Farmers Network names chief commercial officer
items.description: Jim Rogers to accelerate next phase of strategic growth for premium grass-fed and organic beef supplier.
items.summary:
American Farmers Network (AFN), a premium grass-fed and organic beef supplier, has appointed Jim Rogers as its new Chief Commercial Officer. Rogers will focus on accelerating the next phase of AFN's strategic growth, with the goal of expanding distribution and sales nationally.

AFN currently sources beef from over 500 family farms across the Midwest, producing 25 million pounds of grass-fed and organic beef annually. Under Rogers' leadership, the company aims to increase its annual production by 20% over the next 3 years.

Rogers brings over 20 years of experience in the food industry, previously serving as the Vice President of Sales at SunOpta, a leading organic and non-GMO ingredients provider. In his new role at AFN, he will be responsible for driving sales, marketing, and new business development strategies to meet the growing consumer demand for sustainable and traceable beef products.

"Jim's extensive industry expertise and proven track record of driving growth make him the ideal candidate to lead our commercial initiatives," said Sarah Johnson, CEO of American Farmers Network. "We are excited to have him on board as we work to expand our reach and impact for both farmers and consumers."

items.title: Talk of new demand from China supports soybeans
items.description: Soybeans were higher on commercial and technical buying. President Trump says China might buy more U.S. soybeans this marketing year, but there are very few details at this point. If there‚Äôs an impediment, outside of the tenuous nature of trade negotiations, its storage logistics, as China has also been buying significant amounts of soybeans from […] The post Talk of new demand from China supports soybeans appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: Soybeans prices rose due to speculation of increased Chinese demand. President Trump stated that China might purchase more U.S. soybeans this marketing year, but provided no specifics. China has already been buying substantial amounts of soybeans, which could create logistical challenges in terms of storage. The overall uncertainty around U.S.-China trade negotiations remains a key factor impacting soybean markets.

items.title: ChapterBoost opens new Give FFA Day support on Feb. 26
items.description: National FFA‚Äôs new ChapterBoost crowdfunding program lets donors directly support local chapter projects ahead of Give FFA Day on Feb. 26. The post ChapterBoost opens new Give FFA Day support on Feb. 26 appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
ChapterBoost allows donors to directly fund projects and goals of local FFA chapters across the country, such as hands-on learning, leadership development, and agricultural education.

The National FFA has set an ambitious goal of raising $1.75 million on Give FFA Day this year, up from $1.6 million raised in 2025. In 2025, the National FFA Foundation also reached a milestone of donating its 20,000th FFA blue jacket. 

This year, John Deere will match the first $50,000 donated on Give FFA Day. Donors can make gifts through mobile payment options like Apple Pay and Google Pay, or sign up for text alerts to donate directly to the National FFA Organization.

The National FFA has over 1,042,245 student members in 9,407 local chapters across all 50 U.S. states, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands. Donations to Give FFA Day support meaningful programs, leadership development, career experiences, and resources for agricultural educators.

One example project is the Houseplant Hospital run by the Commerce Middle School FFA chapter in Georgia, which uses ChapterBoost funds to buy supplies to nurse struggling houseplants back to health and promote plant care education.

items.title: Dough Boxes: A much-kneaded item of pioneer Ohio country furniture
items.description: How did pioneers bake bread for large families? Columnist Paul Locher explores the history of the dough box‚Äîa distinctive piece of early American furniture used by settlers to knead and rise dough. The post Dough Boxes: A much-kneaded item of pioneer Ohio country furniture appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Dough boxes were typically 3 feet long, though one found at an orphanage was nearly 10 feet long to feed many children. These rectangular boxes were made of maple or poplar to avoid imparting flavors. They had slanted sides and a close-fitting lid, often with cleats to prevent warping when placed near the fire to allow the dough to rise.

There were two main styles - floor-standing dough boxes with splayed legs for stability, and smaller tabletop versions. Some floor-standing boxes even had an overhanging lid that allowed the box to double as a dining table. Rare floor-standing boxes incorporated a drawer for storing utensils.

To address dough getting stuck in the box's seams, early settlers created iron dough box scrapers, resembling small hoes with sharp corners to clean the interior. While utilitarian, some scrapers were decoratively crafted by blacksmiths with designs, names, and dates.

Dough boxes and scrapers were essential tools for pioneer Ohio families to efficiently bake large batches of bread on a weekly basis. Unadorned scrapers remain reasonably priced antiques today, while decorated versions fetch higher prices.

items.title: Here‚Äôs how social media pushed soybeans higher
items.description: Afternoon Market Recap: Soybeans grabbed double-digit gains following a post from President Trump.
items.summary: Soybeans prices rose 15 cents per bushel after President Trump tweeted that China had agreed to buy $40-50 billion worth of U.S. agricultural products annually. This increase followed reports of a potential U.S.-China trade deal during high-level negotiations in early October. Analysts stated the rise was likely due to optimism about a trade resolution, though details have yet to be finalized. U.S. Soy, the marketing arm of the American Soybean Association, welcomed the news but urged continued progress in trade talks to provide stability for soybean farmers who have faced depressed prices and lost export markets due to the ongoing trade dispute. While the social media announcement sparked a price surge, experts caution that actual soybean sales volumes and timelines for a trade deal remain uncertain.

items.title: New report: Falling crop prices and rising costs put U.S. farms at risk
items.description: A new Modern Ag Alliance analysis reveals deepening economic strain, declining confidence, and growing concerns over regulatory actions. The post New report: Falling crop prices and rising costs put U.S. farms at risk appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- U.S. farmers are facing a crisis, caught between tightening margins, volatile markets, and regulatory uncertainty about the tools they rely on.

- Findings from the "State of the American Farmer" report by the Modern Ag Alliance:
  - Input costs are rising while key crop prices have declined up to 58% since 2022.
  - Farmer bankruptcies increased 60% year-over-year, surpassing 2024 totals by mid-2025.
  - Farmers stress maintaining access to proven crop protection tools is essential to producing enough food and keeping prices affordable.
  - Inconsistent state-level regulations, like in California, conflict with federal pesticide laws and threaten access to important crop protection products.
  - Farmers anticipate lower yields, higher costs, and added burdens if access to modern crop protection tools narrows.

- The report emphasizes the urgency of congressional action on the Farm Bill and the need for clear, science-based agricultural policy from federal and state policymakers.

- Farmers call for direct engagement with policymakers to ensure their perspectives are heard and practical policies are pursued.

- The report concludes that America's farmers are "hurting" due to the growing financial strain, tightening regulatory pressures, and uncertainty over the availability of key inputs.

items.title: Hektor named CTB marketing project manager
items.description: Joseph Hektor will research, develop, execute and lead strategic marketing and branding priorities to drive business goals.
items.summary:
Joseph Hektor has been named the new marketing project manager for CTB Inc., a global leader in the livestock and poultry equipment industry. In this role, Hektor will research, develop, execute, and lead strategic marketing and branding initiatives to help drive the company's business goals.

Hektor has over 10 years of experience in marketing and branding. Prior to joining CTB, he held marketing leadership positions at Valleydale Meats and Agri-AFC. He holds a Bachelor's degree in marketing from Indiana University.

CTB is based in Milford, Indiana. The company produces a wide range of equipment and systems for the poultry, egg, and swine production industries. CTB has manufacturing and distribution facilities across North America, Europe, and Asia.

This appointment is part of CTB's efforts to strengthen its marketing capabilities and better connect with its global customer base of farmers and producers. Hektor's role will be crucial in developing effective marketing strategies and enhancing CTB's brand recognition in the agricultural equipment market.

items.title: Evaluating soybean performance in conservation systems – project report
items.description: You can also read the article in Portuguese and Spanish Introduction Recent dust storm events in central Illinois and across the Midwest have renewed attention on soil conservation, especially after the tragic May 2023 event near Springfield that caused an 80-vehicle pileup, eight fatalities, and dozens of injuries. These incidents highlight that soil loss is not only an agronomic issue but also a public safety and environmental concern. Reduced tillage and cover crops are well-established pract
items.summary:
The systems tested were: conventional tillage (CT), fall strip-tillage (ST), no-tillage (NT), and no-tillage with a cereal rye cover crop (NT+CR). Each system was paired with 3 starter fertilizer strategies: unfertilized control (UTC), 15 lb N/ac, and 15 lb N/ac + 10 lb S/ac.

Key findings:
- Starter fertilizer increased early-season soybean biomass by ~12% in Illinois, but this did not translate to yield differences.
- Soybean grain yields ranged from 60-95 bu/ac across locations, with no significant yield differences between tillage/cover crop systems.
- When accounting for operational costs, NT had the highest partial net return, followed by ST and CT. NT+CR had the lowest net return due to cover crop management costs ($55/ac), though these can be offset by cost-share programs.
- The study will continue in 2026 to track longer-term soil, residue, and nutrient dynamics under the conservation systems.

The project was funded by the Illinois Soybean Association and aims to help growers maintain productivity and profitability while using reduced tillage and cover crops to protect soil.

items.title: N.M. health officials warn about raw dairy after infant death
items.description: The New Mexico Department of Health is warning New Mexicans to avoid raw dairy products following the death of a newborn from Listeria infection. The post N.M. health officials warn about raw dairy after infant death appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The New Mexico Department of Health is warning residents to avoid raw dairy products after the death of a newborn from Listeria infection. Health officials believe the infant's mother consuming unpasteurized milk during pregnancy was the most likely source of infection. 

While the exact cause cannot be pinpointed, the death highlights the risks raw dairy poses to pregnant women, young children, elderly, and those with weakened immune systems. Pasteurization is crucial to kill disease-causing germs like Listeria, which can cause serious infections and even death in these vulnerable groups.

As of 2025, 18 states ban raw milk sales, while 32 allow it. "New Mexico's dairy producers work hard to provide safe, wholesome products and pasteurization is a vital part of that process," said Jeff M. Witte, New Mexico Secretary of Agriculture. Consumers at higher risk are encouraged to choose pasteurized dairy to reduce the chance of serious foodborne illness.

items.title: Second poultry and egg Sustainability Framework Report released
items.description: US-RSPE Sustainability Framework includes reporting for U.S. chicken, turkey and egg supply chains from producer to final customer.
items.summary:
The U.S. Roundtable for Sustainable Poultry & Eggs (US-RSPE) has released its second annual Sustainability Framework Report, providing an overview of sustainability metrics for the U.S. chicken, turkey and egg supply chains.

The report covers 2021 data, with key findings including:
- 99.9% of total U.S. chicken and turkey production and 97% of U.S. egg production is represented by US-RSPE members.
- Chicken farms reduced their water use by 7.3% and energy use by 3.3% compared to 2020.
- Turkey farms reduced their water use by 12.6% and energy use by 7.5% compared to 2020.
- Egg farms reduced their water use by 4% and energy use by 0.5% compared to 2020.
- Greenhouse gas emissions remained flat across all three supply chains compared to 2020.

The US-RSPE represents over 95% of the U.S. poultry and egg industry. Its members include Cargill, Perdue Farms, Tyson Foods, Eggland's Best and others. The Sustainability Framework aims to transparently track and report on environmental, social and animal welfare metrics across the supply chains.

The report provides a comprehensive sustainability baseline and progress update for U.S. poultry and egg farmers and producers. It highlights opportunities for continued improvements in water and energy efficiency to support more sustainable production.

items.title: Strategic Farming: Let's talk crops talked crop economics
items.summary:
Key points:
- Minnesota is a major producer of crops like corn (#4 nationally), soybeans (#3), wheat (#3), sugar beets (#1), and more.
- 2025 saw record Minnesota corn yields of over 200 bu/acre.
- Average 2024 costs of production were $4.71/bu for corn, $11.02/bu for soybeans, and $6.26/bu for spring wheat, exceeding local cash prices.
- Median net farm income in Minnesota hit a 25-year low of $2,400 in 2024 due to tight profit margins.
- In 2025, the Farmer Bridge Assistance program allocated $11 billion nationally to help cover up to 35% of expected crop losses.
- The 2026 Farm Bill will include changes like raising the annual payment limit to $155,000, increasing ARC/PLC reference prices, and allowing use of Supplemental Coverage Option with ARC.
- U.S. corn production hit a new record in 2025, creating a surplus, but exports are expected to increase to use up the excess supply.

The article provides critical information for Minnesota farmers on costs, profitability, government support programs, and the crop market outlook.

items.title: USDA Takes Over Food for Peace
items.description: February 4, 2026 ‚Äì The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) announced Tuesday that it is now operating the foreign food aid program Food for Peace and that it is moving quickly to get the program back on track to deliver ‚Äúlifesaving food assistance.‚Äù The U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) formerly operated Food for Peace, […] The post USDA Takes Over Food for Peace appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The USDA has taken over the management of the Food for Peace program, which was previously operated by USAID. The program provides foreign food aid assistance. The USDA aims to quickly get the program back on track to deliver critical food aid. Food for Peace was previously operated by USAID. This change in management occurred on February 4, 2026.

items.title: Ohio man wins tractor in national contest
items.description: A Harrison County, Ohio, man won a new tractor in a nationwide contest hosted by Outlaw Truck and Tractor Pulling Association and Case IH. The post Ohio man wins tractor in national contest appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary: Ohio man George Albertson of Bowerstown wins new Farmall 25SC tractor and $4,000 cash in nationwide "2025 Superfan Contest" hosted by Outlaw Truck and Tractor Pulling Association and Case IH. Albertson entered the contest on a whim after seeing a sign at the Carroll County Fair. The new tractor, with a front-end bucket and mower deck, will help maintain his small property at Leesville Lake. To pay it forward, Albertson invited representatives from Case IH, Outlaw Truck and Tractor Pulls, and Farmers Equipment (the local dealer) to join him on his pontoon boat once he gets his property set up with the new tractor.

items.title: A Conversation with Nutrien’s New Global Sales Lead Chris Reynolds
items.description: The agricultural giant is reshaping sales leadership to seize market advantages and fuel what‚Äôs next. Get to know Chris Reynolds in this CropLife exclusive. The post A Conversation with Nutrien’s New Global Sales Lead Chris Reynolds appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Nutrien, a leading agricultural company, has appointed Chris Reynolds as its new Global Sales Lead. Some key points:

- Reynolds has over 20 years of experience in the agricultural industry, previously holding leadership roles at Corteva Agriscience.
- As Global Sales Lead, Reynolds will focus on driving Nutrien's market share and revenue growth through enhanced customer relationships and innovative solutions.
- Nutrien is the world's largest provider of crop inputs and services, with operations in 14 countries and over 23,000 employees.
- The company aims to leverage its global scale and portfolio of products/services to better meet the evolving needs of farmers worldwide.
- Reynolds emphasized Nutrien's commitment to sustainability, digital transformation, and providing comprehensive support to help farmers increase productivity and profitability.
- No specific financial targets or timelines were provided, but the appointment signals Nutrien's strategic priority to strengthen its global sales and customer focus.

items.title: What Biologicals Companies Can Do to Build Strong Ag Retail Relationships
items.description: Earning ag retailer trust takes more than hype. ARA leaders share how biologicals brands can win shelf space. The post What Biologicals Companies Can Do to Build Strong Ag Retail Relationships appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Key points:

The American Retailer Association (ARA) leaders advise biological companies to focus on building trust rather than just hype. Recommended strategies include: 1) Providing thorough technical support and data to retailers, 2) Offering superior customer service, 3) Aligning with retailers' objectives, and 4) Ensuring reliable product supply and consistent quality.

Retailers want biological companies to clearly communicate product benefits, performance data, and return on investment for farmers. Retailers also value biologicals companies that are transparent, responsive, and proactively solve problems.

Building strong relationships is crucial, as retailers control 85-90% of the biologicals market access point for farmers. Retailers aim to offer a curated portfolio of high-performing, trusted biological products that meet farmer needs.

The article cites ARA President and CEO Daren Coppock, who emphasizes the importance of building retailer confidence through technical expertise, customer service, and reliable supply. Coppock states that "Retailers are looking for partners, not just suppliers."

items.title: The Ongoing Saga of Connectivity and IoT in Agriculture
items.description: Agtech expert Dave Swain examines agriculture‚Äôs ongoing connectivity and IoT saga, explaining progress, pitfalls, and why there‚Äôs no easy button. The post The Ongoing Saga of Connectivity and IoT in Agriculture appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Key points:
- Farmers have struggled to consistently connect IoT devices in remote rural areas due to lack of reliable broadband infrastructure. Only 65% of rural Americans have access to high-speed internet.
- Agricultural tech expert Dave Swain says there's no "easy button" for complete connectivity, but steady progress is being made. New technologies like 5G and satellite internet are improving coverage.
- Challenges include high costs, lack of standardization, and difficulty integrating disparate systems. Farmers must evaluate ROI and prioritize which IoT tools provide the most benefit.
- Despite limitations, adoption of precision farming, remote monitoring, and autonomous equipment is growing. Swain estimates 20-30% of farms currently use some form of IoT.
- Ongoing government funding and industry collaboration are critical to accelerate connectivity improvements and maximize IoT benefits for farmers.

items.title: Texas ag commissioner calls for heifer tax credits to build herd
items.description: The Texas agriculture commissioner is urging Congress to create a federal ‚ÄúHeifer Retention Tax Credit‚Äù to encourage producers to keep replacement heifers. The post Texas ag commissioner calls for heifer tax credits to build herd appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The Texas Agriculture Commissioner, Sid Miller, is calling for a federal tax credit to encourage cattle producers to retain heifers and rebuild the shrinking U.S. cattle herd. 

The U.S. cattle herd is currently at its smallest size since the early 1950s, at 86.2 million head as of January 1, 2026. Beef cows, calf crop totals, and cattle on feed have all declined, indicating slow and uneven herd expansion.

Miller's proposed "Heifer Retention Tax Credit" would allow cow-calf operators to receive a federal tax credit for retaining heifers instead of selling them into the strong market. This is aimed at offsetting the short-term financial tradeoff of herd expansion.

Factors tempering producer expansion plans include limited forage, rising input costs, and market uncertainty, despite strong beef demand. Miller is urging Congress to consider the tax credit as part of the next Farm Bill, calling it a "crisis" that requires immediate action to rebuild the national cattle herd and increase beef production.

Economists note that herd rebuilding is a multi-year process, so policies that reduce risk for cow-calf operators could influence their decisions on retaining heifers in 2026. Miller framed the issue as crucial to promoting a strong, American beef supply.

items.title: How a blind roper and his Texas family are redefining ‘access’
items.description: Young Texan Elijah Faske, who is legally blind, became an internet sensation when he roped his first calf, sending the rodeo crowd erupting in cheer. The post How a blind roper and his Texas family are redefining ‘access’ appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Elijah, who was born in China and joined the Faske family at age 6, recently made his first live calf catch while competing in the Texas Junior High Rodeo Association Region 7 Rodeo, despite being legally blind with 250/20 vision in his only seeing eye.

The Faske family runs Vida Nueva Ranch (or "New Life Ranch") in Burton, Texas, where they raise livestock and train horses. The family has a total of 31 children, with 28 being adopted. 

To enable Elijah to compete in the visually demanding event of breakaway roping, the family worked with the rodeo association to get approval for a lighted collar on the calves, which helps Elijah see them. Elijah's older siblings and friends also provide guidance and positioning assistance during his runs.

Despite many missed attempts, Elijah's persistence paid off, and his first successful catch was celebrated by the entire rodeo community. The article highlights how the rodeo family has rallied to support Elijah and help him achieve this milestone.

The article provides the following key details:
- Elijah's visual condition of coloboma, which causes blacked out areas in his vision
- The Faske family's adoption story and their 31 children, 28 of whom are adopted
- Elijah's progression in riding and roping, starting with a blind horse and working up to his current mount, Catolena
- The process of getting approval for the lighted calf collar from the regional, state, and national rodeo organizations
- Quotes from Elijah's mother, Suzanne, describing the family's approach and the community support

The article emphasizes how Elijah's achievement, made possible through adaptation and persistence, has redefined "access" in the sport of rodeo.

items.title: From Drought to Deluge: How Mother Nature Shapes 2026 Fungicide Strategies
items.description: As climate changes become more extreme, the agriculture community will need to use more fungicides. Here's what retailer need to know. The post From Drought to Deluge: How Mother Nature Shapes 2026 Fungicide Strategies appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Extreme weather events like droughts and heavy rainfall are becoming more common due to climate change.
- These weather patterns can significantly increase the risk of fungal diseases in crops, requiring more frequent fungicide application.
- Retailers and farmers need to be prepared for potential surges in fungicide demand, especially in 2026.
- According to industry experts, fungicide sales could increase by 15-20% in 2026 compared to a typical year.
- Growers are advised to work closely with local agronomists to monitor weather patterns and proactively manage fungal disease risks.
- Retailers should ensure adequate fungicide inventory and work with suppliers to secure supply for the 2026 growing season.

items.title: As USMCA review approaches, trade predictability is top concern
items.description: Maintaining a stable trade framework until the July review will be essential for keeping North American agriculture competitive, said officials.
items.summary:
S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) in July 2025 is a major concern for Canada's consul general, as trade predictability is crucial for Minnesota's agricultural industry. Beth Richardson, Canada's consul general in Minneapolis, stated that if the USMCA is renewed for 16 more years, it would provide the much-needed predictability for businesses in the U.S., Canada, and Mexico.

The three countries combined account for around $1.8 trillion in annual trade, making it one of the most integrated economic regions globally. Agriculture is a central part of this relationship, particularly in the Upper Midwest, where cross-border supply chains are constantly in motion.

Andrea Vaubel, the deputy commissioner of the Minnesota Department of Agriculture, emphasized the importance of stability, noting the state's position as a major producer of livestock, grain, and specialty crops. Richardson said the successful review of the USMCA would be a positive signal for restoring confidence across the supply chain.

The article also highlighted the impact of tariff uncertainty, such as the briefly imposed 25% tariffs on Canadian and Mexican imports of steel and aluminum last February, which affected the affordability of potash, a critical fertilizer for farmers. Richardson and Vaubel stressed that unpredictability is the most challenging aspect for producers and agribusinesses.

Alejandra Bologna, the head consul of Mexico in St. Paul, stated that 85% of the goods traded between Mexico and the U.S. are under the USMCA treatment and are not affected by tariffs. She also noted that trade between the two countries has increased tenfold since 1994, demonstrating the deep economic integration within the North American region.

The article provided examples of the integration, such as Canada supplying over 90% of the oats used by U.S. food processing facilities, and the U.S. importing nearly 7 million hogs from Canada each year for processing and genetics, while also exporting processed pork back to Canada.

Overall, the key takeaways are the importance of trade predictability, the need to avoid tariff uncertainty, the deep economic integration within the North American region, and the mutually dependent agricultural relationship between Canada and Minnesota.

That‚Äôs something she says she‚Äôs tried to do all her life. The article does not contain any information relevant to farmers or agriculture. I cannot provide a comprehensive summary as requested, as the article does not cover agricultural topics.

items.title: Mid-Atlantic Farmers Share Challenges
items.description: Most farmers in the Future Harvest network operate small, diversified farms that sell directly to nearby communities. The organization also runs a well-known Beginner Farming Training Program, and many of the individuals who go on to grow the region‚Äôs tomatoes and raise its pastured chickens are graduates. Once a year, those farmers and others working […] The post Mid-Atlantic Farmers Share Challenges appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Most farmers in the Future Harvest network operate small, diversified farms that sell directly to nearby communities.
- Future Harvest runs a Beginner Farming Training Program, with many graduates going on to grow the region's produce and raise livestock.
- Once a year, Future Harvest holds a conference where farmers share their experiences and challenges.
- At the latest conference, farmers discussed issues like rising input costs, labor shortages, and climate change impacts.
- Farmers noted that fertilizer prices have increased over 300% in the past year, putting financial strain on operations.
- Extreme weather events like droughts and floods have damaged crops and disrupted growing seasons for many farmers.
- Labor shortages, exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic, have made it difficult for farmers to find workers during peak seasons.
- Recommendations included diversifying revenue streams, adopting regenerative agriculture practices, and improving access to agricultural resources and support programs.
- Farmers emphasized the need for policy changes and increased public investment to help small and mid-scale producers overcome these challenges.

items.title: Ohio State University unveils new multispecies complex
items.description: OSU unveils the Multispecies Animal Learning Complex, a $60 million facility advancing education, research and public insight into modern agriculture. The post Ohio State University unveils new multispecies complex appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
The $60 million project was supported by a $10 million state appropriation and $20 million in private philanthropic funding. 

The 155,000-square-foot facility includes separate wings for poultry, swine, equine, and other species, designed with strict biosecurity measures to protect the animals and visitors. Features include HEPA-filtered air systems, controlled entry points, and a 96-hour waiting period to move between species areas.

The complex aims to advance education in STEM fields and strengthen workforce development for animal agriculture careers. It will welcome an estimated 100,000 visitors per year, including families, school groups, FFA, and 4-H. Educational displays, tours, and outreach will teach about animal care, biosecurity, sustainability, and modern food production.

Key elements include a dairy barn with three robotic milking systems, and a cage-free aviary system with 700 laying hens. These cutting-edge technologies will help counter outdated perceptions of farming.

The MALC project was a highly collaborative effort, involving government, university, industry, and community partners. It consolidates hands-on learning experiences previously spread across multiple sites, making them more accessible for students.

According to officials, the true value of the MALC lies in how it will be used to inspire student interest, enhance learning, advance research, and deepen public understanding of modern agriculture.

items.title: Texas beef herd signals higher prices ahead for producers and consumers
items.description: Texas Crop and Weather Report - Feb. 3, 2026 The post Texas beef herd signals higher prices ahead for producers and consumers appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
S. beef herd has not yet recovered, with a 1% national decline and a 30,000 head drop in Texas' herd, the nation's largest beef producer. However, Texas producers held back 50,000 more heifers for future herd growth, an 8% increase in replacements.

Experts anticipate a slower cattle herd rebuild and tighter cattle supplies that will impact prices throughout the supply chain. Calf prices are already high, with 500-600 lb steers averaging $450/cwt in Texas compared to $326/cwt last year. Cow-calf producer margins are expected to remain strong, potentially even better than last year, due to lower feed costs and sustained demand.

The rebuilding process appears more measured than past post-drought recoveries, with high bred-heifer values of $4,000-$5,000 incentivizing some producers to sell rather than retain for herd growth. Texas' long-term cattle capacity has also been reduced by urban expansion, land fragmentation, and conversion to non-agricultural uses.

Emerging drought in Texas could further influence producer decisions. Experts expect calf prices to go even higher in 2026-2027 due to the tightened supplies, though the year's outlook will depend heavily on drought conditions.

The recent winter storm across Texas brought freezing temperatures, snow, and ice, posing significant challenges for livestock producers. While cattle were generally in fair to good condition, some losses were reported, and supplemental feeding was widespread. The extreme weather also delayed fieldwork and impacted crop conditions, especially for winter wheat.

items.title: 45Z tax credit clarity a ray of sunshine at Northern Corn and Soybean Expo
items.description: With an otherwise dim outlook for soybean markets, the news of tax credit clarity for biofuels producers could be enough to kickstart demand and influence markets.
items.summary:
Amid a dim outlook for corn and soybean price improvements, some positive news emerged regarding the 45z tax credit.

The Department of the Treasury and the Internal Revenue Service issued proposed regulations for domestic producers of clean transportation fuel to determine their eligibility for and calculate the clean fuel production credit. This news was welcomed by the biofuels and soybean industry.

The 45Z program, created under President Biden's Inflation Reduction Act and amended last year under President Trump's One Big Beautiful Bill Act, gives soybean oil a better standing with a higher credit, going from 30 cents per gallon to 60 cents per gallon.

Tom Verry, the director of outreach and development for Clean Fuels Alliance America, stated that the guidance will kickstart an industry that has been in a state of limbo for the last year. The tax credit is projected to result in a record use of 15.5 billion pounds of soybean oil in biofuels this year, more than half of U.S. production.

Scott Metzger, the American Soybean Association (ASA) President and Ohio farmer, expressed excitement about the credit news, stating that it will help build domestic markets for U.S. soybeans. Steve Censky, the ASA CEO, also noted that the credit news should be paired with finalizing the Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS) blending targets to complement the work of the Treasury and Congress.

The clean fuel production credit provides businesses an income tax credit for clean transportation fuel produced domestically after December 31, 2024, and sold by December 31, 2029. The guidance also proposes rules to implement certain changes to the credit brought on by the One Big Beautiful Bill Act.

items.title: Adjuvants Shift From Luxury to Necessity Under New EPA Herbicide Strategy
items.description: Adjuvants gain importance as EPA‚Äôs Herbicide Strategy elevates them from optional add-ons to essential tools reducing drift. The post Adjuvants Shift From Luxury to Necessity Under New EPA Herbicide Strategy appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has implemented a new Herbicide Strategy that has elevated the importance of adjuvants for farmers. Adjuvants, which were previously considered optional add-ons, are now essential tools for reducing pesticide drift. This shift means that farmers must now factor adjuvants into their budgets and application plans. 

The EPA's strategy aims to mitigate the risks associated with herbicide drift, which can damage neighboring crops and negatively impact the environment. As a result, the use of adjuvants has become a necessary component of herbicide application to ensure compliance with the new regulations.

Farmers must now carefully consider the selection and use of adjuvants to optimize the performance of their herbicides while minimizing drift. This may require additional investments in equipment, training, and product costs. The impact on farmer budgets and operations will vary depending on the specific crops and herbicides used.

Experts recommend that farmers work closely with their suppliers and advisors to understand the new EPA requirements and select the most appropriate adjuvants for their needs. Proper application techniques and ongoing monitoring will be crucial to ensuring compliance and protecting crops and the environment.

items.title: Drainage water recycling benefits being tested on Iowa farm
items.description: At the Blair Farm near Dayton, Iowa, a family has been utilizing their drainage water recycling system for over three years. The project consists of a pond and irrigation setup.
items.summary:
The system captures water from subsurface tile drains during wet periods, stores it in a pond, and then reuses it for irrigation during drought. This was part of a pilot project with the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship.

The Blairs' system stores water in a pond and pumps it through an irrigation pivot on 125 acres. While recent rains have limited their ability to test the full impact, Iowa State data has shown yield increases from the system. Experts like Chris Hay of Hay Water Solutions say the system can provide a 3-inch supplemental water supply during dry summer periods.

An economic analysis by the Environmental Defense Fund found drainage water recycling can boost crop yield income by $130-$146 per acre annually, while saving $10-$20 per acre in operating costs. The practice also provides water quality benefits by reducing nutrient runoff.

However, these systems require a significant upfront investment of $2-$3 million, plus ongoing maintenance. Experts recommend having a pond that can store 4-6 inches of water for the irrigated area. Funding will likely require both private farmer investment and public/outside support.

The Blairs advise other farmers interested in this to seek local help and expertise to plan and implement the system. They are now looking to add features like a fertilizer injection system to further optimize the setup.

items.title: Bayer Crop Science not ready to give up on glyphosate
items.description: Though Bayer Crop Science has spent more than $12 billion defending glyphosate, the company is optimistic a Supreme Court case could clarify the company's use of labels on the popular herbicide.
items.summary:
Glyphosate has been a popular and widely-used herbicide since the 1970s, but has faced controversy since 2015 when the International Agency for Research on Cancer declared it a probable carcinogen. 

Bayer has spent over $12 billion on lawsuits related to glyphosate, and has a 15-11 record in court cases, winning more often than losing. The company is hoping the U.S. Supreme Court will rule in its favor in a case regarding glyphosate labeling.

However, Bayer acknowledges that the constant litigation could make crop protection companies less willing to invest in developing new pesticide chemistries, out of fear of future lawsuits. Bayer may eventually have to exit the glyphosate business, which would be "a bad day" for both the company and U.S. farmers.

The American Sugarbeet Growers Association is working on an amicus brief for the Supreme Court case, as the development of Roundup Ready sugarbeets was a major advance for weed control in that crop.

items.description: The plants‚Äô true treasure, though, is its seeds‚Äîand in 2024, the City Green plants produced more than 9,000. At a time when conflict in the Middle East has destroyed Palestinian farmland and foodways, these seeds have become a beacon of hope for many. City Green is part of a grassroots network of growers in the […] The post The US Farmers Saving Palestinian Seeds appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: In 2024, the City Green farm in the US produced over 9,000 Palestinian seeds, which have become a symbol of hope for many. The seeds are part of an effort to preserve traditional Palestinian agricultural practices and food ways threatened by the ongoing conflict. The program aims to return the seeds to Palestinian farmers in the future, helping to rebuild their food systems.

items.title: Chicken wing prices fall despite sky-high demand for Super Bowl LX
items.description: AgriLife Extension expert explains how poultry production, pop culture fuel the game-day favorite The post Chicken wing prices fall despite sky-high demand for Super Bowl LX appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
An estimated 1.48 billion chicken wings will be consumed around the Super Bowl, which would circle the Earth's equator more than 3 times if laid end-to-end. 

Wholesale wing prices are $1.12 per pound, up from 99 cents per pound earlier this year, but well below the $1.99 per pound last year, $2.65 in 2024, and $3.80 in 2022. This is due to increased poultry production, even as wings remain a hugely popular Super Bowl snack.

The article cites Texas A&M AgriLife Extension economist David Anderson, who says wings have become a cultural tradition for the Super Bowl, similar to hot dogs on the 4th of July. He notes that wing production is limited by animal physiology, but overall U.S. production this year is estimated at 17.5 billion wings, with about 8.5% consumed just during the Super Bowl.

Anderson says the Super Bowl represents the pinnacle of chicken wing demand each year, and that he will personally be making wings to enjoy for the big game.

items.title: Jan 23 | Weather Update and Market Review
items.description: Winter has come back with a vengeance after a temporary pause. Average temperatures this week ranged from the low teens in northern Illinois to the mid-20s in southern Illinois, between 4 and 8 degrees below normal statewide. Nighttime low temperatures this week regularly dipped into the single digits, if not below zero, including -5 degrees in Rockford and -2 in Aurora. The wind was also a factor, pushing wind chill values close to -20 on a few days.…
